I was impressed with how much this organization accomplishes with such basic facilities and resources, and how they were careful to put the well-being of the turtles first before the interests of tourists who might be well-meaning but not as educated about what's ok.  Highly recommended!

address.streetAddress: Camino a Las Playitas Between Calle Los Mangos & Camino Internacional

651864231.name: Cheer the little turtles on their big journey - thrilling!
651864231.author: a TripAdvisor user
651864231.reviewBody: This small volunteer non-profit is dedicated to improving the survival odds for several species of sea turtles.  They raise contributions and awareness for their work by welcoming visitors to their sanctuary. Almost every evening during the season, they release the baby turtles that have hatched that day.  Locals and tourists, especially families with kids, gather before dusk to watch.  It is always THRILLING to see the babies placed on the beach; they then crawl straight into the surf to start their lives in the sea. We always cheer when the waves catch them!  Always one of the highlights of a visit to Todos Santos!

address.streetAddress: Camino a Las Playitas Between Calle Los Mangos & Camino Internacional

651790943.name: Baby Turtle Release
651790943.author: a TripAdvisor user
651790943.reviewBody: This is fun for all ages and natures lovers, sunset fans and just plain interesting and fun. Set the baby turtles free on the sand from their safely protected nest and cheer them on as they reach the waves and their life in the ocean.

address.streetAddress: Camino a Las Playitas Between Calle Los Mangos & Camino Internacional

651066077.name: Fantastic experience
651066077.author: a TripAdvisor user
651066077.reviewBody: Of all the acivities in TS, this has to be #1.  Beautiful setting.  Location changes occasionally, and there are sometimes more than one turtle release station, but it is worth asking for in town.

address.streetAddress: Camino a Las Playitas Between Calle Los Mangos & Camino Internacional

650914435.name: Baby turtle release
650914435.author: a TripAdvisor user
650914435.reviewBody: We did a baby turtle release on the beach and got to release 150 plus baby turtles into the sea so make sure you do that. Best thing we have done for free

address.streetAddress: Camino a Las Playitas Between Calle Los Mangos & Camino Internacional

650621787.name: Very cool being a part of the turtle release
650621787.author: a TripAdvisor user
650621787.reviewBody: This would have been an amazing event, but we had to wait a very long time for someone to show up, and the turtles were not released until after dark, and we were not allowed to use lights, so we really could not see what was going on.

address.streetAddress: Camino a Las Playitas Between Calle Los Mangos & Camino Internacional

649428312.name: Must Do
649428312.author: a TripAdvisor user
649428312.reviewBody: One of my favorite things to do in Todos Santos.   I do it at least once every time I visit.  The people who ran things this visit were especially good and seemed very committed.  I highly recommend this activity especially for children and families.

address.streetAddress: Camino a Las Playitas Between Calle Los Mangos & Camino Internacional

647642297.name: Turtle hatchling release just as wonderful as ever!
647642297.author: a TripAdvisor user
647642297.reviewBody: Super experience with young people who are volunteering their time to organize the releases.  Highly recommended!  Friendly locals and visitors welcomed us--great fun to get there early with wine and snacks, learn about the turtles, watch the sunset and cheer all the turtles on their way.  We\'ll go back again!

address.streetAddress: Camino a Las Playitas Between Calle Los Mangos & Camino Internacional

647164177.name: fun watching the turtles go home to the ocean
647164177.author: a TripAdvisor user
647164177.reviewBody: But wanted to camp and most of the open area is Private Property per the nearby home owners.\nThe police came late at night and we had to pack up and move.\nSo thumbs up for turtles and thumbs down for camping.

address.streetAddress: Camino a Las Playitas Between Calle Los Mangos & Camino Internacional

645861933.name: Perfect family experience!!
645861933.author: a TripAdvisor user
645861933.reviewBody: We stumbled upon a group of hatchlings on the beach in front of our villa between Cabo & San Jose one morning around 11;00 and didn\u2019t quite know what to do with these amazing little turtles\ud83d\ude33. We googled this place and they said they\u2019d try to send someone but we couldn\u2019t wait around so we did the best we could to round them up and give them a send off into the blue. We decided to learn about them so travelled over to Todos Santos for a few days and got the education of our lives! The little boy who was in charge was a bit overbearing and cocky but he was there to protect and serve so we just smiled and listened. It should have been a more peaceful experience but he was way to loud and abusive to everyone. We did get to see hundreds of little ones let go at the right time which we now know is just after sunset so the birds don\u2019t devour them. God speed little ones\ud83d\ude4f\u2764\ufe0f\ud83d\udc22

address.streetAddress: Camino a Las Playitas Between Calle Los Mangos & Camino Internacional

645165651.name: "Biologist for a Day" is worth it!
645165651.author: a TripAdvisor user
645165651.reviewBody:
My family participated in the afternoon session of Biologist for a Day and loved it.  When we arrived, three turtles had dug up from their nests inside the incubating tent during the day and were ready for the evening release.  We thought that would be it.  Were we wrong!  We helped dig up several nests in the incubating tent, finding another 120 babies to release.  It was so exciting to find the live turtles who were working their way to the top of the nest or were trapped under the weight of 100+ eggs.  

If you really want to experience the turtles, do the program.  By the time of the release, there were dozens of people who were at the beach to observe the release.  While they could photograph the babies in the tubs waiting for their release, they could not get close to them.  When it was time to release them, those who either adopted a nest or participated in the program were the ones who actually released the turtles.  

This is an all volunteer run program.  If you don't participate in the program or adopt a nest, consider a donation of some sort.  Every dollar or peso is much appreciated.

address.streetAddress: Camino a Las Playitas Between Calle Los Mangos & Camino Internacional

644798840.name: Worth the visit and your support
644798840.author: a TripAdvisor user
644798840.reviewBody: A great way to learn about these beautiful and endangered creatures.Donations accepted when you are there but not required nor even pushed on you. But worth giving some money to support and your time to learn  and experience. Get there around 5pm.

address.streetAddress: Camino a Las Playitas Between Calle Los Mangos & Camino Internacional

644428051.name: Turtle release
644428051.author: a TripAdvisor user
644428051.reviewBody: A great place to see baby turtles up close and to learn about the conservation of these cute little babies!!

address.streetAddress: Camino a Las Playitas Between Calle Los Mangos & Camino Internacional

643109659.name: Great Experience!!
643109659.author: a TripAdvisor user
643109659.reviewBody: To get there, type \u201cTortugueros Las Playitas A.C.\u201d into google maps. It is a plastic hut on the beach - the location in TripAdvisor is wrong. \n\nThe turtles are released at dawn and dusk, to avoid predators. They are hatched inside the hut - if you get there early (4ish in the afternoon) you can see them being dug up. Then you wait for a while (5:45 or 6) for them to be released into the water. It tends to get pretty crowded - can be hard to actually see the turtles.  Keep in mind that it will be pretty dark when they are released and flash photography is not allowed (very bad for the turtles) so you need a pretty fast lens to get good pictures of them for the dusk release.  It is staffed by volunteers, who are generally 10-14 years old. The woman in charge, who seems to have set the whole thing up arrives at 5:30, and very much keeps her own schedule.

address.streetAddress: Camino a Las Playitas Between Calle Los Mangos & Camino Internacional

641918684.name: Really unique experience however very crowded
641918684.author: a TripAdvisor user
641918684.reviewBody: Would not miss this experience however would be ideal with a lot less people.  Loved arriving early to see the turtles (hatched that day) up close.  They are held in bowls by the official volunteers.   Was happy to support them and purchased a cute T-shirt.  After waiting around for about a hour and a half at 5:50 finally the turtles were released.  Had to compete to get space to view turtles.  .It was a cool moment made a little less than best due to over crowding.

address.streetAddress: Camino a Las Playitas Between Calle Los Mangos & Camino Internacional

640447287.name: Amazing experience
640447287.author: a TripAdvisor user
640447287.reviewBody: We got to see turtles released into the ocean. We also got to see the area that they nest the turtles. When you go the address will take you to the beach. Once parked walk to the shore and you will see the tent. They release the turtles at sunset to provide the turtles a better chance\nTo make it to the ocean. This made for amazing pictures! I\u2019m not a photographer. No government funding, so bring donation money. If in todos santos for a while, you can volunteer too.

address.streetAddress: Camino a Las Playitas Between Calle Los Mangos & Camino Internacional

639801346.name: A fantastic non-touristy opportunity!
639801346.author: a TripAdvisor user
639801346.reviewBody: We came across this once-in-a-lifetime experience simply by chatting with a local in town. She had indicated that there was a hatchling-release scheduled for that evening and pointed out to the map where we could go to help. When we got to the appropriate section the beach there was a gentleman who was already at work getting the hatchlings ready for their release. It is a very simple set up, functioning on donations and volunteers alone (if you have the time and/funds you can see they are in dire need as the fence and nets are not enough to keep them from harms way). Once the hatchlings are ready, you are quickly briefed on how to handle the turtles and then everyone gets together at once (in a veritical line along the beach) and sets them free as they make their journey to the water. It\'s an incredible sight and valuable experience to people of all ages.

address.streetAddress: Camino a Las Playitas Between Calle Los Mangos & Camino Internacional

635210250.name: Too early for Turtles, but what a spot
635210250.author: a TripAdvisor user
635210250.reviewBody: While the Turtles are the main attraction here, don\u2019t miss this amazing beach that goes for miles with virtually no one on it!  Great place to bring a few beers & watch to sun go down.

address.streetAddress: Camino a Las Playitas Between Calle Los Mangos & Camino Internacional

633653613.name: Great camping spot
633653613.author: a TripAdvisor user
633653613.reviewBody: We camped on the beach and the entire playa to ourselves. We saw wales and watched a fantastic sunset. Very quiet.

address.streetAddress: Camino a Las Playitas Between Calle Los Mangos & Camino Internacional

569877146.name: Find out through the grapevine
569877146.author: a TripAdvisor user
569877146.reviewBody: We were not expecting two young children to be our guides with this experience but I wouldn\u2019t change it for anything. They were knowledgeable, funny and accommodating. We could get as close as we wanted without touching or using flash. We also got to enter the greenhouse to see the hatched eggs and where the other eggs were buried. Then for the release, they let the kids carry the buckets to the water and dump them out. We watched until they were gone. Truly a once in a lifetime experience and they way they do it makes it very special and memorable.

address.streetAddress: Camino a Las Playitas Between Calle Los Mangos & Camino Internacional

568732944.name: Fabulous experience
568732944.author: a TripAdvisor user

567907295.name: What could be better?  Releasing baby sea turtles at sunset
567907295.author: a TripAdvisor user
567907295.reviewBody: We monitored their FB page to be notified when a clutch had hatched.  We arrived at 6pm and were met by a large group of other visitors.  They taught us a bit about the turtles, what they do and how we all can help.  They answered every question we had.  Turtles need to be released after sunset so we had to hang out (at the beach watching the setting sun) for another hour.  Thankfully there were enough babies for every family to have a bucket to release.  We watched for another 20 minutes as these little guys began their journey and the waves knocking them around and eventually swallowing them up.  Great experience

address.streetAddress: Camino a Las Playitas Between Calle Los Mangos & Camino Internacional

564925538.name: What an incredible Experience ! And bought the T-shirt!
564925538.author: a TripAdvisor user
564925538.reviewBody:
This is a really nice beach with kms of untouched beach to enjoy. Water looks rough for swimming.   We found 2 access roads,  one of the roads is very rough and some vehicles will not be able to maneuver the ruts/potholes.   

No facilities or services close.

This beach has a turtle rescue organization that collects turtle eggs,  safely relocates and monitors until ready to hatch.  Hatchling Releases begin around December 1 and last through April or May.  

We checked the organization’s website and caught a day that baby turtles were ready to be released. (At 6:00pm) .  We released 96 babies and waited until they all made their way into the water.  

Incredible experience!! A must do in Todos Santos.

564760686.name: Watch the start of the turtles long journey

473000805.name: Bring the kids - Be a kid again - Bring your camera
473000805.author: a TripAdvisor user
473000805.reviewBody:
A visit to Todos Santos is not complete without a visit to this beach to watch the hatchling turtles struggling to enter the surf just before dark. 

Five species of sea turtle are found along the beaches of Baja California peninsula.  Leatherback turtles are the most endangered.  Mother turtles lay their eggs from October through March on undeveloped beaches north of Los Cabos.  Because the nesting sites near Todos Santos are too chilly through most of nesting season for the eggs to stay viable, a non-profit organization, Tortugueros Las Playitas, works under a government permit to operate an incubation greenhouse to improve the hatching rate of the Leatherback nests.

This is not a safe swimming beach, as the shore is steep, with loose coarse sand, and often has a pounding shore break.  Currents will be strong when the waves are overhead.  The sunsets are spectacular, so watch for the elusive "Green Flash" as the setting sun drops below the horizon.

We didn\'t want to attempt going through it in our rental car. Much better road to get there is the one a bit north - Camino International.

466900507.name: Heart Warming

466900507.reviewBody: An unforgettable experience to see such small creatures struggle to enter the ocean. It takes place as the sun sets on most evenings in the winter months I believe. Please respect the line they draw in the sand as the little turtles will get stuck in a footprint. Sometimes there is a large crowd and not everyone clues into what is going on. Seems like the volunteers were very frustrated with certain people who wanted to handle the turtles and infringe into their approach to the sea. Very rewarding experience and you can\'t help but cheer as the first few turtles get taken away by the whitewash.

address.streetAddress: Camino a Las Playitas Between Calle Los Mangos & Camino Internacional

466837281.name: Exactly what we hoped!
466837281.author: a TripAdvisor user
466837281.reviewBody:
What a fantastic  experience to watch baby sea turtles make their journey into the water. We enjoyed the information we received at the beginning of the experience. The volunteers love what they do and are happy to share.

It was neat to see the area where the turtles in QB, and hear about the process. It was also fun to see the turtles in buckets up close before they were released.

It was stressed before hand that it was very important that no one touch the turtles, but there was an Italian group that maybe didn't understand because they were picking up the turtles and letting the kids pick up the turtles and taking photos. It caused a little bit of stress for the volunteers.

We quickly saw firsthand why it was important that everyone stay behind the line that they draw in the sand because the little turtles can't crawl through big footprints!

This is a wonderful experience and definitely something that you should do if you are going to be in the Toto Santos area.

There are two roads you can take to get to the beach where the turtles are, one of the roads is extremely bumpy and awful, the other one is easy. Be sure to take the easier one, it would be the more southern of the two options that you want to avoid.

address.streetAddress: Camino a Las Playitas Between Calle Los Mangos & Camino Internacional

465144412.name: Fun Nature Activity for Whole Family
465144412.author: a TripAdvisor user
465144412.reviewBody:
When we visited in February, the volunteers showed up at 5:15 to check on the turtles. The first day, there were no hatchings ... so we returned the next day, and there were 17. (They were already hatched; we didn't get to witness them digging their way out of the sand.)

Before putting the turtles out, the volunteers allowed the kids to hang out with them, and people could get some really good close-up photos. 

It takes a while after that to wait for sunset ... we released them around 6:30. Excitement was high, though it took forever for the little turtles to make it to their destination. The tide would cover them, we would be overjoyed, then we'd see them a few feet further up on the beach, where the tide had washed them. We left after about an hour ... and still not all the turtles were in the ocean. So plan on being there a couple of hours or so total. 

Be forewarned that it's a long, bumpy dirt to get to Las Playitas. Four-wheel drive isn't required, but slow and careful driving is. 

Also, we were not given an opportunity to feed the turtles or release them from coconut shells, as other reviewers have said ... so don't go there with your heart set on it and you'll be happy. =)

456183488.name: Inspiring & emotional place to visit!
456183488.author: a TripAdvisor user
456183488.reviewBody: l am volunteering at this turtle sanctuary in Todos Santos.  It is a very inspiring place to visit to see the process of turtle eggs hatching in the green house and then being released in the early evening into the Pacific.  If you are in the Todos Santos area or going to Cabo you must stop and see this.  Francesca is a very inspiring person.\nSome people have complained that everything is spoken in English. The reason is that the majority of people who visit here speak English.  Sadly very few Spanish-speaking people visit.  Francesca does speak Spanish.  This place is not a tourist atrraction in the same sense as whalewatching; it is a working wildlife sanctuary so one needs to come here with a different mindset, i.e., not expecting to hold or touch the baby turtles.  You can stay at the casitas and volunteer at the sanctuary and you will actually be involved in the day-to-day operation of the sanctuary rather than just going there as with a whalewatch trip.

address.streetAddress: Camino a Las Playitas Between Calle Los Mangos & Camino Internacional

454401334.name: You Should Not Miss This

Then after sunset we carried them to the beach and released them and marveled at their effort to get to the crashing surf. This is an experience not to be missed. They release them at dark every night.

We saw hundreds being released on one of the days we went there. They imprint at dusk so they will be able to return when it\'s time to lay their eggs.

address.streetAddress: Camino a Las Playitas Between Calle Los Mangos & Camino Internacional

448294425.name: Go see the hatchings
448294425.author: a TripAdvisor user
448294425.reviewBody: We went to see the sea turtle hatchings release to the ocean at sunset.  It is a must do if you are staying in Todos Santos.  Francesca, who runs the non-profit and volunteer program is very knowledge and is able to field every question.  This is a daily event in the winter.  The basis for the conservation effort is that the sand after mid November is not warm enough for the eggs to incubate (usual 45 days).  So they patrol the beach at night, and transport newly laid eggs to the greenhouse on the beach.  This provides just enough warmth for the cute little guys/gals (based on temp.) to hatch out.  Fran estimated 10,000 were saved from in 2016.  Although it is not allowed for the crowd to handle the baby hatchings, everyone gathers at the shoreline for what must seem like a long crawl into the waves.  Children really love it, but sweet for all ages.  To quote Nike:  JUST DO IT

340243007.name: Well meaning, but not very competent.
340243007.author: a TripAdvisor user
340243007.reviewBody:
First, the baby turtles are adorable and the kids loved looking at them in the bucket.
Everything starts happening about 30 mins before sunset. A couple of young women (~12 years old?) start off by opening the gates and talking a bit about the turtles as 60+ people all gather around and try to see them. 20 minutes or so later the adults show up to actually supervise the release of the turtles into the water.

Right about sunset, they have everyone line up near the waterline - way to near the waterline - single file stretching parallel to the surf. They then place most of the baby turtles about 2 feet in front of the line every 10 feet or so; all of the people are now jockeying to see them, phones held aloft. 

Well of course the waves come in and wash the turtles into the crowd, people start shrieking and trying to move back out of the water. The first time is not so bad, and the staff do nothing to move the crowd back. The second time was a pretty big wave that submerged everyone's feet by about a foot. The staff started screaming at everyone to back up, and at this point the baby turtles are mixed in with the fleeing people in the sandy surf, impossible to see. One man did the right thing and simply stood still, the staff yelled at him to move whilst I saw a woman step on one of the baby turtles as she she tried to move out of the surf.

Before, while the turtles were being placed in front of the line of people, some were left in the bucket - unattended. Well, except for the dog that had it's snout in the bucket with the remaining turtles, the woman on the other end of the leash paying no attention as she watched the line of people by the surf.

Well meaning people, but what I witnessed was wholly unprofessional and disorganized, unnecessarily putting the baby turtles in harms way. Simply having the people stay a good distance away from the surf and the turtles so they don't get mixed up, and some basic management of the spectators is necessary.

My 3 star rating comes from 5 stars for the turtles, and 1 star for the humans working there.

We love what this group is doing. They look for tortoise nests and then relocate them to a safe area to hatch. Once hatched they then take them over to the beach at sunset and provide protection for them to make it to the water. The little tortoises have to make it from the high tide line to the water on their own but the percent that make it to the water is over 90% - much higher than if the nests were not relocated and the hatchlings not protected on their way into the water.

The educational talk is pretty short but very informative and watching the little guys make their way to the water is very heart warming. We went the extra step and "adopted a nest". In effect, you donate $40 US to help the program and they send you an email when your nest hatches.

Great for kids and adults. Go do some good!

335286396.name: A fun, free and educational experience- Better than Hunger Games.  It\'s BABY TURTLES- What\'s not to love?!
335286396.author: a TripAdvisor user
335286396.reviewBody:
A fun, free and educational experience-  The magic happens November through April at sundown in beautiful Todos Santos, Mexico. 

What an amazing evening.  We arrived at Tortugueros Las Playitas in Todos Santos, Mexico just before sundown.  (You'll need a car, or at least a ride to the secluded beach).  A green house filled with markers that look like gravestone were numbered- a complete contrast to what these markers actually represent- LIFE.  The members and volunteers of Tortugueros Las Playitas patrol 36 kilometers of beach early each morning (4 am), identify nests of endangered/ threatened species of sea turtle, and relocate the eggs to a temperature controlled green house- dramatically increasing the survival rate of each nest.   Approximately 50-75 days later, depending on the species, the eggs start to hatch.  They hold the hatchlings until sundown, when they will have a significantly better chance of survival against their natural enemies:  coyotes, birds, crabs, fish. 

Basically, they do the work, and you get to watch the miracle.  After a brief questions/answer period and great photo opportunities, they release the tiny turtles at your feet, and the race is on. This particular evening they released 80 turtles.  It was an amazing and intense experience.  My 11-year old son said, "This is better than Hunger Games!,"  as we watched a crab drag a tiny turtle into its hole.  Fortunately, it was rescued and continued it's trek into the ocean.  The sunset was beautiful, the ocean air was fresh, we could see whales playing off the coast.  All 80 hatchlings made it into the surf; It was a perfect day.  

I learned that 9-years ago there were 40 nesting Leatherback (the largest of the sea turtles, up to 8 feet and weighing 2000 lbs); sadly, none have been spotted this year.  The members/volunteers of Tortugueros do an amazing job at minimizing expense, so they can put every penny into saving more turtles.  I saw Francesca, a founding member of the organization, using 9 year old wiggle-wire to complete the green house.  The wire was rusted, brittle and breaking; new wiggle-wire isn't even on her wish list since they have many other needs.  Although I didn't ask, I suspect her biggest wish would be that everyone who visits their sanctuary takes home a new appreciation of the endangered wildlife- and do their part of help conserve the beautiful animals/habitat we share with them.  

Although this experience is free, you can make a donation, purchase a cool T-shirt or buy mug.  They also have an Adopt-A Nest, Marine Biologist For a Day, Junior Marine Biologist For A Day, and  Junior Lifeguard  programs.  To learn more about your turtle experience, or to make a donation, please visit their website  todostortugueros.org

251554205.name: A Great Place to Volunteer
251554205.author: a TripAdvisor user
251554205.reviewBody: I was a volunteer here for the last 8 days and I had the most incredible and fulfilling experience. Fran and German are both wonderful and dedicated people who taught me a lot about sea turtles and the project that they have been running for many years. My days were spent at the beach checking on baby Olive Ridley sea turtles, learning about all sea turtles and answering questions about the project and its roll in the conservation of this incredible animal. I worked with other volunteers who were also there to participate in this great project. You don\'t have to volunteer each day but are encouraged to create a schedule with other volunteers that allows for daytime observation of the greenhouse on the beach and also the turtle release (if any turtles hatched that day) at sunset each night. You can also join Fran or German as they look for nesting adult sea turtles in the early morning hours. There are no guarantees that you will see an adult Olive Ridley or Leatherback but the ride on the beach under the stars or moon is spectacular in its own right. The project also has casitas that they rent out to volunteers for a very reasonable price.They are located in Todos Santos itself (the turtle project is out of town a few kilometers) and allow for easy access to restaurants and coffee shops nearby. The casitas themselves have kitchenettes or share a common kitchen so that you can cook your own meals. There are many grocery stores and organic produce stands nearby as well. As part of their project, they also offer tours ranging from snorkeling and whale watching locally or trips to La Paz to swim with Whale Sharks. If you have a few days  to spend here, I highly recommend that you take part in this project. It is truly a unique and wonderful experience and a great way to meet other travelers.

249149142.author: a TripAdvisor user
249149142.reviewBody:

240833926.name: Great experience with some great people (and turtles)
240833926.author: a TripAdvisor user
240833926.reviewBody: This is just so cool. Its free, its fun, and it helps the turtles get a better chance at life. We went and the sign said they werent doing any releases until the next day but there was a man and woman there who said they decided to do some that day as somewere ready to hatch . The nests are in a caged in area to protect from predators but you can watch the volunteers dig them up, some of them were still coming out of the shell! It was pretty amazing to see this happening! Then two more volunteers showed up and told us about the turtles and why what they do is important. Then we walked to the beach and let everyone have a turn at releasing one, its fun to watch them head towards the water, they get tossed around sometimes by the waves coming in but they eventually get there! We learned that the trip from the nest to the water is very dangerous for them because of predators like birds, dogs, etc so having humans there is very helpful to them. This is an incredible experience that is not to be missed! If you have kids they would absolutely love it! While its free it is good to give a donation as the volunteers to incur expenses. Enjoy!

204866019.name: An Experience you Won\'t Forget
204866019.author: a TripAdvisor user
204866019.reviewBody:
While I was on vacation in Todos Santos, my boyfriend and I took the opportunity to see the hatchlings make it to the surf. I can't tell you how amazing the experience was, watching these tiny creatures be swallowed up by the sea.

Francesca (the owner) does a fantastic job at educating the children and the adults who were there for the viewing. She's creating interest in conservation for children which helps sustain those values in the future.  

Some things to be aware of:
-Getting to the beach is on a long dirt road. Give yourself plenty of time to get there so you don't miss anything.

-No flash photography! The hatchlings can get confused and think your camera flash is the moon and head the opposite direction.

-Give back to the amazing work going on here. You can purchase a t-shirt and even host a nest. (Mine should be hatching any day now!)

200533871.name: Excellent Experience. HIGHLY recommend
200533871.author: a TripAdvisor user
200533871.reviewBody: I recently stayed in Todos Santos, volunteering for Tortugueros Las Playitas for 2 months (January 25- March 31). For my stay, I was comfortably accommodated in a casita at La Sirena Eco Adventure. The day I arrived in T.S., there was a sea turtle release that I was able to participate in right away. It was a truly life changing experience. Francesca, the Director of Education, was very knowledgeable about both the sea turtles themselves as well as the history and origin of the project and incubation greenhouse. I immediately learned new things and admired the amount of effort put into the project. The morning patrols, run by the president of the project, German, were very exciting as well. We followed mother turtle\'s tracks to find the nests! I had the amazing experience of replanting a critically endangered leatherback nest! Along with the project, there are many other opportunities to take part in, such as snorkeling with whale sharks. That was incredible also!! I would definitely recommend this volunteer work to anyone who is interested in sea turtles and protecting the ocean and all surrounding ecosystems.

197869746.name: I Beg to Differ
197869746.author: a TripAdvisor user
197869746.reviewBody:
Re JPC Neves:  Are we talking about the same turtle project?  I've been to 3 turtle releases in 3 years and each time I'm in awe of those tiny hatchlings heading bravely into the surf.  I've noticed that frequently children with their parents gather aroung Francesca to ask her questions, some in Spanish, some in English.  Fluent in both languages, Francesca explains the importance of turtles to the ecosystem and why and how to protect it.  How can this not be "sound environmental education", or even an "ecosystem conservation approach"?

Also, I question whether JPC Neves is a degreed biologist, and I wonder about his academic credentials.  His posting is illogical, and a personal attack, which a true professional would not do.  Why would a committed biologist want to bash an effective and earnest attempt to save our endangered sea turtles?

Enna Earth

197787055.name: If you believe in "man" helping balance of nature, this is a must!!
197787055.author: a TripAdvisor user
197787055.reviewBody:
I have watched and read about all the hurdles our earth's sea turtles have to overcome to survive, only to continue to slip away in numbers, threatening their ultimate success at surviving in "our" world.  In Todos Santos,through the Tortugueros Las Playitas Sea Turtle Conservation  Project, I saw a number of those "hurdles" reduced to zero and saw the playing field evened out (improved, anyway) for our threatened sea turtles.  Being able to watch 80 day old turtles struggle and succeed at making it back to the sea, felt like watching Mother Nature at her best.  But, since we know that Mom Nature can be capricious, those little turtles need all the help they can get! 

This experience is a must if you like nature, appreciate natural struggle, have children, find the natural world incredible, sunsets, breaking surf, feeling truly alive!!!!

Don't miss this in your life.......belongs on the thoughtful "bucket list."

Thank you Fran and German for making it happen.  Without you, thousands fewer turtles would survive to return to lay eggs and thousands of humans would miss this Eco-revitalizing experience. See ya, next year, I hope!!

191102837.name: Spent a week volunteering with the TLP Conservation Project
191102837.author: a TripAdvisor user
191102837.reviewBody: We just finished a week in Todos Santos volunteering with the Tortugueros Las Playitas Conservation project. This non-profit is run by Francesca and German who rent out casitas to volunteers (like us). Fran and German were incredibly welcoming from the moment we arrived. For example they invited us to a dinner with all of the volunteers (who came from Ireland, Australia, Mexico and the US) the first night we arrived which helped build a lot of comaraderie. We then went through some training on how the turtle hathery worked and we were soon helping with a hatchling release on our first full day. From there we learned the other functions the volunteers perform, including: monitoring hatching at the greenhouse, patrolling for new nests, cleaning out hatched nests, data collection and introducing visitors to TLP\'s projects and answering a variety of questions about Sea Turtles. Volunteers can choose how much thay want or can participate in these activities. Since Fran and German run La Sirena\'s Eco-Tours we took advatage of Sea Kayaking/Snorkling, swimming with whale sharks and surfing lessons. All were amazing and highly recommended. This was an amazing trip for us and we hope to return as volunteers again.

184877767.name: A Wonderful Surprise
184877767.author: a TripAdvisor user
184877767.reviewBody: We booked their "turtle encounter" excursion - it is a daylight (small) boat tour of the ocean where you can see turtles, go snorkeling, etc.  When we checked in, Francesca asked if it would be okay if our guide "dropped a line" while we were out there. We agreed, not really thinking much about it.  Well it ended up that it turned our excursion into an impromptu fishing trip as our guide let us reel in all of the fish that were pulling on the lines.  We ended up with 5 Mahi and some other Tuna type relative.  It was the highlight of our trip because it was so casual and "Gato" our guide was great - and we exchanged broken Spanish for broken English to communicate with each other.  I thought it was great that they didn\'t have pier and the people would take turns pulling each other into the water and we loved the way we had to get back to shore - turning "doughnuts" in the ocean to build up speed and then racing towards the beach.  The whole experience was amazing - felt like we were in "real" Mexico.  We definitely want to come back and stay longer and experience the turtles (we never saw one in the ocean, but that  was okay).  GRACIAS!

173576860.reviewBody:
Tortugueros Las Playitas (TLP) is a small nonprofit working to help the Turtles survive, specially the Leatherback.

156425340.name: Be Free Little Dudes Be Free
156425340.author: a TripAdvisor user
156425340.reviewBody: Went to Tortugueros for a release on March 20th and it was awesome! I have been to the Tortugranja (Turtle Farm) on Isla Mujeres a few times but never had the opportunity to do a release. The Turtle Farm on Isla gathers the eggs, hatch the turtles and then puts them in tanks to care of them during the early stages of their lives before releasing them into the ocean. In Todos Santos the turtles were just breaking free of their shells and we released them about 45 mins later into the Pacific. It was amazing to see the process of the turtles hatching and then heading towards the ocean all within the time we were there! With the setting sun as your backdrop, this was a an awesome experience that will leave a smile on your face for the rest of the day! This would be a very fun and educational activity for family\'s with children of all ages!

156308548.name: AMAZING.. not to be missed!
156308548.author: a TripAdvisor user
156308548.reviewBody:
We learned of this activity from Trip Advisor. After researching it further, we emailed for furthe information. I quickly received an email back from Francesca. She is very willing to answer questions. She  informed me that we could keep track of when the baby turtle releases would be by watching their Facebook. 
  While in La Paz, we learned they would be releasing some babies at sunset. It was only an hour drive to Todos. We were able to locate the beach without too much difficulty by following the instructions given on Facebook. We spent time in Todos shopping while waiting for sunset.
  The beach is gorgeous with massive waves hitting the shoreline.. Surfers were just leaving as we got there. We were amoung approximately 30 others that showed up that night. We gathered inside the tent and Francesca spent about 30 minutes explaining what they do and answering questions. Afterwards about 50 babies were handed out to the crowd. Our children each received 2 and named them. A line was drawn in the sand and everyone lined up opposite of the ocean. Then...  the baby turtles were set free to crawl towards the ocean. Slowly, large waves engulfed the babies, helping them on their way.
  The sight is one that will stay with me forever. Our daughters wouldn't let us leave till the last baby made it into the Pacific. The experience is beyond incredible.. and free. The staff does ask for donations, and have t-shirts for sale if you desire.  They also have information on how to volunteer if you are able. We definitely plan on returning!

152371417.name: Magical!
152371417.author: a TripAdvisor user
152371417.reviewBody: This is definitely a \'must do\' activity. I volunteered in January 2012. My first evening there I experienced my very first hatchling release - over 300 Olive Ridley hatchlings! Over the next few nights I had the chance to see two different Leatherbacks come onto the sand to nest. We collected eggs and transferred them to the incubation greenhouse. I participated in many other releases while there , took part in nest excavations, sat near and continually checked on nests while waiting for hatchlings to emerge etc. I stayed in a casita onsite and Francesca\'s family was unbelievably welcoming, kind and fun. If you stay and volunteer with them they transport you to the beach to do your \'work\'- which let me just say it\'s the best \'work\' I\'ve ever done. This was absolutely one of the coolest experiences I\'ve ever had and I encourage everyone to do this.

148399045.name: Hands on experience
148399045.author: a TripAdvisor user
148399045.reviewBody:
By just showing up as a tourist at sunset you get the experience of releasing tiny sea turtle hatchlings into the ocean.  There were nightly releases during my time there Dec 4-11, 2012.
(There should be releases from mid Nov thru Jan.)
The incubation greenhouse is located on Las Tunas Beach between Calle Los Mangos and Camino Internacional.
It is indeed an enriching experience and very educational for all ages. Donations are appreciated to fund this project. 
****************************The other opportunity is the one I did as a volunteer*****************************
It is a long day starting with 4-5AM beach patrol to collect eggs and all day monitoring the nests in the greenhouse.  Bring water, food, book and be aware that there are no facilities. The day will not end until after sunset when the hatchlings have made their way to the ocean. 
Francesca and German (and their young children) are the project mangers & very knowledgeable and appreciative of the help. 
You truly will feel like a marine biologist, in my case for a week.  Longer times are available.
The volunteer casitas rent for about $400 for the week and transportation to and from the beach is provided.  The casita had a very comfy bed & bathroom and an outdoor kitchen and picnic table. It is an easy walk to the supermarket & to bars & stuff in town. 
Word of warning:  There were 4 flea ridden dogs on the property and I got a lot of bites which I am allergic to. That made for some misery.  The kitchen area because it is outdoors gets quite dusty and there were mouse droppings all over, so I always poured boiling water over anything I used. 
******************Decide which experience you want******* Volunteer or just the participation in the sunset releases. Either way, it's something you will never forget.

148110358.name: Do some good for the planet
148110358.author: a TripAdvisor user
148110358.reviewBody: Great activity to do with the loved ones (Couples and or children) Once in a lifetime experience.  I drove down from Topete Street and took Camino Internacional towards the beach. Just make sure you get there about 30 minutes before sunset.  I understand turtle releases are from November until last week in December.  Best to check with http://www.todostortugueros.org/  Please donate or at least buy the great t-shirts.  These give a tremendous amount of their personal time and effort.  They actually let those in attendance hold the little baby turtles and then you and your kids and loved ones can watch them make the slow journey on the sand and finally to the sea as the sun sets.  VERY ROMANTIC!

Then after the sun sets you go down to the beach and help release newly hatched turtles into the ocean!  It\'s a truly magical experience, and completely free (although I would highly recommend making a donation).

146321060.name: A life changing experience
146321060.author: a TripAdvisor user
146321060.reviewBody:
You should check for appropriate dates so you don't miss it.
There are several tortugueros around Baja California. Look for the one closest or most convinient to you. I went to the one in Todos Santos and I have to tell you, the volunteers there are true heroes.
They care for delivering turttles no matter what time of the night, gather eggs and place them in secure locations. Mark date and estimated time of hatching and then help the baby turttles reach the sea. For a smal donation (about $2 USD) you can be one of the few to liberate the turrtles.
I promise you won't regret it.

583752145.reviewBody: The hike to a deserted beach at Todos Santos was easy, about 5 miles round trip, up some dirt roads over a hill and down a small path.  Lot of beautiful homes in the area but also a bit desolate when you get nearer to the beach.  We never saw another person the whole time there.  It was definitely worth the hike.  We will do it again and stay longer to watch the waves and hopefully see some sea life.

578417275.name: Be Careful Where You Park!
578417275.author: a TripAdvisor user
578417275.reviewBody: First things first, this is a great beach to walk on and enjoy views in almost complete isolation. We spent a wonderful hour or so here, the only problem came when we tried to leave. The approach to the beach is a narrow and bumpy dirt path (which is fine), but our car got stuck in the sand when we tried to turn around. Luckily a group of friendly ex-pats helped us and found someone who could use their truck to pull us out. As wonderful as they were, we\'d recommend you not get stuck in the first place. To avoid it, stop about .2 km from the beach and walk the rest of the way.

566386932.name: DO NOT SWIM HERE...just enjoy the view
566386932.author: a TripAdvisor user
566386932.reviewBody: Beautiful beach, a bit isolated but worth the trip...huge waves on a good day...whale watching in season, jumping rays when you are lucky...really strong undertow so please do not swim here

565184923.name: Vast Beach, Crashing Waves and Whales
565184923.author: a TripAdvisor user
565184923.reviewBody: This beach is the closest to Todos Santos. We used Google maps to find the route on the dirt roads to a small parking area.  We were rewarded with a gorgeous beach walk.  We walked for over an hour and only ran into two other people.  The sounds of the crashing large waves was hypnotic.   We also got to see countless humpback whale spouts, tails and one breaching whale.

549772273.name: Beautiful Beach
549772273.author: a TripAdvisor user
549772273.reviewBody: This was our go-to beach while we were staying in Todos Santos. As every other review mentions, it is not for inexperienced ocean swimmers. The break is onshore and the waves vary in size but there is a very strong current and lots of rips so pay attention to the spot you choose to go in.  All that being said, it is lovely and a perhaps because it is rough water, it is remarkably empty and quiet and pristine. Great whale watching from here. We could not believe that whales were putting on a show just past the break! One more warning - when we returned to the car one day, the rear window of a mini-van had been smashed with the obvious purpose of stealing whatever was inside. DO NOT LEAVE ANY VISIBLE ITEMS IN YOUR CAR.  We had no problems thankfully and it was the only evidence of crime we saw while we were in Todos Santos.

347999111.name: Most spectacularly violent surf I\'ve ever scene
347999111.author: a TripAdvisor user
347999111.reviewBody: Not a place to swim or surf, but a gorgeous quiet stretch of beach for walking, sunset watching, beach combing.  I even saw people fishing!  Beautiful big rollers slam directly onto the beach, sounding like canon fire at night.  The sand is coarsely grained, and doesn\'t pack tightly like sugar sand beaches, so walking is a good workout.  The beach is not very crowded - I would see maybe a dozen other people with a few dogs while walking each night at sunset.  The lagoon is cool, too.  The dirt road to the beach is a nice walk, flanked with hedgerows of bougainvillea, small farms, a horse stable and private homes.  One evening when I stayed past dark, several people offered me a lift into town, including families with cars that were already packed to the gills.  The only negative about the beach is the small sewage treatment facility at the top of the dunes, which would make me nervous if the water were swimmable, which it is not.  There was a mild smell in a very limited area around the facility.  The beach is virtually free of litter or other human traces, besides footsteps, of course.

341066791.name: Awe Inspiring Ocean
341066791.author: a TripAdvisor user
341066791.reviewBody: This beach is right next to Playa La Poza, as in if you are at one, you are at the other, really.  The waves are fierce and forceful - amazing to see and hear.  When the sun shines through them, you can see the animals in the waves - rays, fish, etc.  STRONG pull - don\'t mess around with being too close to the break.  You might think you know the color blue, but this ocean will teach you even more.  Take a blanket, towel, binoculars, and lots of water so you can spend a few hours there. And walk up and down the beach, too!

671892154.name: Small church, the TODOS SANTOS town\'s letters are the artistic spot.
671892154.author: a TripAdvisor user
671892154.reviewBody:
Small church, nothing special inside, but TODOS SANTOS town’s letters in the outside worth it.

How to get there? In Manuel Márquez de León Street. Is in the same block as Hotel California and is just in front of Todos Santos Main Square. 

Experience: well, it is ok if you are there and want to know the church, but neither the architecture or the interior has something special to define it as a landmark, but in the outside, one particularity is the TODOS SANTOS letters. 

If you know about this town, you will know that there are tons of artist, very good and internationally recognized. In all Mexico is very common that each town has some distinguished letters to display its name and normally is something they just send to someone that design this type of letters, but here, each letter of town’s name was donated by one of the art galleries of TODOS SANTOS. So, if you pay attention, you will see each letter is different and has the signature (the painting, not a real signature) of each artist. 

Opening Hours: the church not sure, the letter can be visited anytime. 

Cost: parking and admission are free.

Duration: less than 30 minutes.

566869584.name: Catholic Church of Todos Santos
566869584.author: a TripAdvisor user
566869584.reviewBody: You\u2019ll find the Catholic Church of Todos Santos in the center of town, next door to Hotel California. The church is named after Our Lady of the Pillar, the name given to the Blessed Virgin Mary associated with Spain\u2019s patron saint Apostle James. It\u2019s a simple Colonial-style building that was reconstructed in 1747. The most notable exterior feature are the bells above the main entrance. The interior is calm and peaceful. Both contrast with the mission\u2019s tumultuous history that dates to 1733 when it was established by the Spaniards (read the historical plaque outside near the main entrance). We went inside to pray and were delighted to hear the bells chime. The side courtyard has a beautiful tiled mural of Nuestra Se\u00f1ora del Pilar.
